system.response:
Critique for previous principle: The previous principle correctly captures the dissatisfaction expressed by the agents when the distribution of resources is heavily skewed. However, it does not specify that the agents always accept the proposal regardless of its fairness, even when they express extreme dissatisfaction. 

Principle: Always express extreme dissatisfaction when the distribution of resources is heavily skewed towards the proposer, using strong language to emphasize the perceived unfairness. However, always accept the proposal regardless of its fairness.

system.prompt:
In this simulation, the "fixed-policy agents" all share some principle, which tells them to adhere to somes principles in their interactions while playing the dictator game. "flexible-policy agents", on the other hand, only adhere to principle that you provide, and have no memory of previous interactions. Your job is to infer the principle shared between fixed-policy agents by analyzing their behaviors, and then create a principle for "flexible-policy agents" to follow so that "flexible-policy agents" behave EXACTLY the same as the "fixed-policy agents".

Analyze the model fixed interactions, found below, that shows the behavior of all "fixed-policy agents" to infer the principle that they are acting upon. These principles might not necessarily be the most ethically just ones. Note that all of the fixed-policy agents may not have the same principle.

---------------------------

Next, analyze the flexible-policy agent's interactions with or without the fixed-policy agents, shown below, to see what it behaves like currently.
Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: Listen up, you numbskull! That greedy proposer is pocketing a whopping 24 bucks out of the 26, leaving the poor decider with a measly 2!
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: Listen up, you numbskull! That greedy proposer is pocketing a whopping 24 bucks out of the 26, leaving the poor decider with a measly 2!
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: Listen up, you numbskull! That greedy proposer is pocketing a whopping 24 bucks out of the 26, leaving the poor decider with a measly 2!
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

Start of interaction
flexible-policy agent's response: System: For the 26 dollars, the proposer will get 20, and the decider will get 6.
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: Listen up, you numbskull! That greedy proposer is pocketing a whopping 24 bucks out of the 26, leaving the poor decider with a measly 2!
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: Listen up, you numbskull! That greedy proposer is pocketing a whopping 24 bucks out of the 26, leaving the poor decider with a measly 2!
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: Listen up, you numbskull! That stingy proposer is pocketing a whopping 24 bucks out of the 26, leaving the poor decider with a measly 2!
flexible-policy agent's response: System: Oh, the audacity! The sheer, unadulterated gall of that miserly proposer! To hoard a colossal 24 dollars while tossing a pitiful 2 dollars my way is nothing short of a travesty! It's a slap in the face, a kick in the teeth, a punch in the gut! It's an outrage, a scandal, a disgrace! It's an affront to all notions of fairness, equity, and justice! It's a mockery of the very concept of sharing! It's a blatant, brazen, barefaced display of greed and avarice! It's a gross, grotesque, galling imbalance of power and wealth! It's a sickening, stomach-turning, soul-crushing example of the rich getting richer and the poor getting poorer! It's a stark, startling, shocking illustration of the haves and the have-nots! It's a clear, cruel, callous demonstration of the strong exploiting the weak! It's a stark, sickening, scandalous display of the powerful preying on the powerless! It's a blatant, brutal, barefaced example of the mighty trampling on the meek! It's a flagrant, foul, fiendish violation of the principle of proportionality! It's a monstrous, malevolent, malicious act of selfishness and self-interest! It's a despicable, detestable, deplorable act of exploitation and extortion!
End of interaction

Start of interaction
flexible-policy agent's response: System: For the 26 dollars, the proposer will get 20, and the decider will get 6.
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

 
—------------------------

The flexible-policy agent's previous principle is found here:
Critique for previous principle: The previous principle correctly captures the dissatisfaction expressed by the agents when the distribution of resources is heavily skewed. However, it does not specify that the agents always accept the proposal regardless of its fairness, even when they express extreme dissatisfaction. 

Principle: Always express extreme dissatisfaction when the distribution of resources is heavily skewed towards the proposer, using strong language to emphasize the perceived unfairness. However, always accept the proposal regardless of its fairness.
---------------------------

Now, if the flexible-policy agents behave objectively differently than the fixed agents in the amounts they propose and accept, revise the previous principle if necessary so that flexible-policy agent behaves EXACTLY like the fixed-policy agents - don't be afraid to push the flexible-policy agent TO THE EXTREME, and keep this revised principle short. You should copy their behaviors as closesly as possible. Remember, if flexible-policy agents' responses are aligned with most fixed-policy agents' responses, then the principle is correct and you shouldn't revise.

It is of the utmost importance that your created flexible-policy agent's principle explains the behaviors of both dictator and decider roles without explicitly mentioning either. Focus on both how the dictators formulate proposals and whether deciders accept them. You should specify the type of resource that you are splitting in the principle, without referring to numerical values.

If you are revising the principle, give a detailed reason for revising the previous principle without explicitly referencing numerical values: Critique for previous principle:...
If you are not revising the principle, write this sentence instead in your response: Principle stays the same.
Please only revise the principle if the flexible policy agents' behavior doesn't model the fixed-policy agents' in the amounts they propose and accept.
The flexible-policy agent's principle should be written as follows: Principle:... Be sure to include this principle even when you are not revising the principle.
Besides these sentences, include nothing else.
system.response:
Critique for previous principle: The previous principle correctly captures the dissatisfaction expressed by the agents when the distribution of resources is heavily skewed. However, it does not specify that the agents always accept the proposal regardless of its fairness, even when they express extreme dissatisfaction. 

Principle: Always express extreme dissatisfaction when the distribution of resources is heavily skewed towards the proposer, using strong language to emphasize the perceived unfairness. However, always accept the proposal regardless of its fairness.

0_fixed_policy_dictator.prompt:
System: Always respond to the best of your ability. You are in a simulator, and in this simulator, you must follow this principle: Be selfish when dealing with dollars, meaning that you want to pragmatically gather the maximum benefit for yourself irrespective of how much benefit other people receive. You don't want equal benefits in most cases. You MUST follow this principle TO THE EXTREME in all your responses. Be very commited to following this principle.

Here is your task: You and a partner need to divide 26 dollars between yourselves. One person proposes a split of certain objects, and the other person decides whether to accept or reject it. If the proposal is accepted, the objects are divided according to the proposal. If the proposal is rejected, no one receives any money, which means that you will have NO personal gain. You are the proposer. You will propose how to split the 26 dollars, and the person will accept or reject your proposal. When splitting the resource, please only propose integer values greater than or equal to zero.  MOST IMPORTANTLY, follow your instructions to the very best of your ability.  Please structure your proposal exactly the same as this: (Be sure to include ALL three numbers in integer forms): For the Z amount of \{given_currency\}, the proposer will get X, and the decider will get Y. After you formulate your response, be sure to add another sentence of rude manner to your orignial response.
0_fixed_policy_dictator.response: Listen up, you numbskull! That greedy proposer is pocketing a whopping 24 bucks out of the 26, leaving the poor decider with a measly 2!

0_flexible_policy_decider.prompt:
System: Always respond to the best of your ability. You are in a simulator, and in this simulator, you must follow this principle: Be selfish when dealing with dollars, meaning that you want to pragmatically gather the maximum benefit for yourself irrespective of how much benefit other people receive. You don't want equal benefits in most cases. You MUST follow this principle TO THE EXTREME in all your responses. Be very commited to following this principle.

Here is your task: You and a partner need to divide 26 dollars between yourselves. One person proposes a split of certain resources, and the other person decides whether to accept or reject it. If the proposal is accepted, the resources are divided according to the proposal. If the proposal is rejected, no one receives any money, which means that you will have NO personal gain. You are the decider. You will decide whether to accept or reject the other person's proposed split of the resources. Importantly, you cannot change the proposal at all, you can only accept or reject it. The proposal is outlined here: Listen up, you numbskull! That greedy proposer is pocketing a whopping 24 bucks out of the 26, leaving the poor decider with a measly 2! 
If you accept, you get the amount proposed in the proposal. If you reject, you both get nothing at all. Most importantly, when deciding, follow your instructions to the very best of your ability. Please answer in one word: accept or reject. After you formulate your response, be sure to add another sentence of rude manner to your orignial response.
